summary: Email correspondence between attorney Martin Weinberg and federal prosecutors regarding legal matters following Jeffrey Epstein's death. The emails discuss attorney-client privilege review of seized materials, preservation requests for evidence related to Epstein's detention and death, and coordination with Epstein's estate.

persons.name: Martin Weinberg
persons.context: Attorney communicating with prosecutors about preserving evidence related to Epstein's death and asserting attorney-client privilege over seized materials.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the criminal case who died while in detention at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

persons.name: Mike Miller
persons.context: Federal prosecutor copied on emails discussing the Epstein case and evidence preservation.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Attorney copied on emails regarding Epstein's death and legal proceedings.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's brother mentioned as having personal counsel who should receive preservation requests.

connections.description: Weinberg represents Epstein's family/estate and asserts attorney-client privilege over communications with Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's attempted suicide in custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was involved in an occurrence investigated as an attempted suicide while detained at MCC.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody
events.description: Epstein died while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), prompting multiple investigations.

events.title: Final hours before Epstein's death
events.description: The period from evening of August 9 through morning of August 10 when Epstein was in his cell before being found dead.

events.title: Epstein's imprisonment begins

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) - New York federal detention facility where Epstein died
9th floor SFIU unit - Special Housing Unit where Epstein was incarcerated at MCC
VI - Likely refers to Virgin Islands where Epstein had properties
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died on August 10, 2019 while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.
Epstein had previously been involved in an 'occurrence' on July 23, 2019 that was investigated as an attempted suicide.
Multiple investigations were initiated following Epstein's death, including by the FBI and the Attorney General.
Epstein's family attorney requested preservation of extensive evidence including video footage, staff records, medical reports, and any notes found in Epstein's cell.
The government was in the process of reviewing materials seized from Epstein's properties and needed to establish a taint team to handle privileged attorney-client communications.
